label: A. A. Sanin
description: А. А. Санину - Alexander Akimovich Sanin (real name Schoenberg ; April 3, 1869 [ 1 ] , Berdichev , Kiev province  – May 8, 1956 , Rome ) – Russian actor, theater director, theater teacher.

label: A. B. Goldenweiser
description: А. Б. Гольденвейзеру - Alexander Borisovich Goldenweiser ( February 26 [ March 10 ]  1875 , Chisinau , Bessarabia province , Russian Empire  - November 26, 1961 , Nikolina Gora , Zvenigorod district , Moscow region , RSFSR , USSR ) - Russian and Soviet pianist , composer , teacher , publicist , music critic , public figure .

label: A. K. Glazunov
description:
А. К. Глазунову - Alexander Konstantinovich Glazunov[a][b] (10 August [O.S. 29 July] 1865 – 21 March 1936) was a Russian composer, music teacher, and conductor of the late Russian Romantic period. He was director of the Saint Petersburg Conservatory between 1905 and 1928 and was instrumental in the reorganization of the institute into the Petrograd Conservatory, then the Leningrad Conservatory, following the Bolshevik Revolution. He continued as head of the Conservatory until 1930, though he had left the Soviet Union in 1928 and did not return.[1] The best-known student under his tenure during the early Soviet years was Dmitri Shostakovich.[2]

Glazunov successfully reconciled nationalism and cosmopolitanism in Russian music. While he was the direct successor to Balakirev's nationalism, he tended more towards Borodin's epic grandeur while absorbing a number of other influences. These included Rimsky-Korsakov's orchestral virtuosity, Tchaikovsky's lyricism and Taneyev's contrapuntal skill. Younger composers such as Prokofiev and Shostakovich eventually considered his music old-fashioned, while also admitting he remained a composer with an imposing reputation, and a stabilizing influence in a time of transition and turmoil.[3]

label: A. P. Chekhov
description: A. P. Chekhov (born Anton Pavlovich Chekhov) was a Russian playwright, short story writer, and physician. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest writers of all time, known for his dramatic works like "The Seagull," "Uncle Vanya," "The Three Sisters," and "The Cherry Orchard," as well as his short stories. He was born on January 17, 1860, and died on July 2, 1904, at the age of 44

label: A. S. Arensky
description: Anton Stepanovich Arensky (Russian: Анто́н Степа́нович Аре́нский; 12 July [O.S. 30 June] 1861 – 25 February [O.S. 12 February] 1905) was a Russian composer of Romantic classical music, a pianist and a professor of music.

label: A. V. Zataevich
description: А. В. Затаевичу - Aleksandr Viktorovich Zatayevich (Russian: Алекса́ндр Ви́кторович Затае́вич; 20 March 1869 [O.S. 8 March] – 6 December 1936)[1] was a Russian music ethnographer and exponent of Central Asian folk music.[2][3]

label: E. Yu. Kreutzer
description: Е. Ю. Крейцер -  August 20 marks the 145th anniversary of the birth of Elena Yulievna Zhukovskaya, née Kreutzer (1875–1961). A pianist, singer, and vocal teacher, she is best known today as the author of memoirs about S. V. Rachmaninoff. She was 18 years old when she felt drawn to music and began taking piano lessons from the then young composer. Their communication developed into a strong, cordial friendship that both of them carried through their entire lives. Sergei Vasilyevich Rachmaninoff admired Elena Yulievna’s willpower, the orderliness of her thoughts, and her ability to stick to a planned lesson plan. She played 4–5 hours a day, solving theoretical musical problems. Even when he was busy or away, Sergei Vasilyevich did not forget to write letters asking for help to his student. These lessons continued from 1893 to 1901. During the summer months, S. Rachmaninov spent long periods of time in the Kreutzer family home. Rachmaninov's future wife, Natalia Satina, was a close friend of Elena Yulievna.

Танееву - Sergei Ivanovich Taneyev ( November 13 [25], 1856 [ 1 ] , Vladimir [ 2 ] [ 3 ] […]  – June 6 [19] , 1915 [ 1 ] , Dyutkovo , Moscow Governorate [ 1 ] [ 4 ] ) was a Russian composer , pianist , music teacher and theorist , and musical and public figure; the younger brother of lawyer Vladimir Taneyev , and a student of Pyotr Tchaikovsky .

label: S. V. Smolensky
description: С. В. Смоленскому - Stepan Vasilyevich Smolensky (October 3 (15) , 1848 , Kazan  – July 19 ( August 1 ) , 1909 , Vasilsursk ) – Russian cultural figure, musicologist, paleographer, choral conductor and teacher.

label: V. I. Rebikov
description: В. И. Ребикову - Vladimir Ivanovich Rebikov ( May 19 (31),  1866 , Krasnoyarsk  – August 4 , 1920 , Yalta ) was a Russian composer , pianist, musical reformer, representative of Russian and European musical modernism, and writer.

label: V. I. Safonov
description: В. И. Сафонову - Vasily Ilyich Safonov ( January 25 [ February 6 ] , 1852 [ 1 ] , Ishcherskaya , Terek Region , Russian Empire [ 1 ]  – February 27, 1918 [ 2 ] [ 3 ] […] , Kislovodsk , Caucasus Governorate [ 2 ] ) was a Russian conductor , pianist , teacher, and public figure. One of the most prominent and authoritative representatives of Russian musical culture in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Rector of the Moscow Conservatory (1889–1905). Chief conductor of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra (1906–1909). Associate of Pyotr Tchaikovsky .

label: V. S. Kalinnikov
description: В. С. Калинникову - Vasily Sergeevich Kalinnikov ( January 1 [13] , 1866 [ 1 ] , First Warrior , Mtsensk district [ 2 ]  – December 29, 1900 [ January 11 , 1901 ] [ 1 ] , Yalta , Tauride province [ 3 ] [ 1 ] ) was a Russian composer and bassoonist .

label: Yu. D. Engel
description: Ю. Д. Энгелю - Yuli Dmitrievich (Yoel) Engel ( April 16 (28) , 1868 , Berdyansk , Tauride Governorate – February 11 , 1927 , Tel Aviv , Mandatory Palestine ) – Russian, German and Palestinian musicologist, translator, folklorist, composer.
